infotable.title: Alternative Fuels Comparison

notes.note: Data Source: U.S. Department of Energy Alternative Fuels & Advanced Vehicles Data Center. Average fuel prices for January 2008, the most recent dataset that includes alternative fuel prices.

infotable.note: Mixtures of ethanol or biodiesel with gasoline are referred to by their alternative fuel concentration. For example, a mixture of 85% ethanol and 15% gasoline is called E85. Pure ethanol is called E100, whereas pure biodiesel is B100.

item.label: Fuel Source
item.data: Crude Oil

item.label: Vehicle Compatibility
item.data: Compatible with vehicles that have standard combustion engines

item.label: Environmental Impacts
item.data: Emissions contribute to air pollution. Not biodegradable.

item.label: Safety Issues
item.data: Highly flammable

item.label: Fuel Source
item.data: Crude Oil

item.label: Vehicle Compatibility
item.data: Compatible with vehicles that have diesel engines

item.label: Environmental Impacts
item.data: Emissions contribute to air pollution. Not biodegradable.

item.label: Safety Issues
item.data: Highly flammable.

item.label: Fuel Source
item.data: Animal fats or vegetable oils, including waste vegetable oils.

item.label: Vehicle Compatibility
item.data: Compatible with vehicles that have diesel engines

item.label: Environmental Impacts
item.data: Reduces hydrocarbons, global warming gases. Uncertain nitrogen oxide emissions.

item.label: Safety Issues
item.data: Non-toxic and biodegradable. Not as flammable as diesel fuel.

item.label: Fuel Source
item.data: Dependent on power plant fuel source (coal, nuclear, hydroelectric, etc.)

item.label: Percent of Gasoline's Energy (per gallon)
item.data: 1KWh has 3%

item.label: Vehicle Compatibility
item.data: Requires a vehicle made to run on electricity.

item.label: Environmental Impacts
item.data: Electric vehicles have zero pollution, but the power plant that generates the electricity may not.

item.label: Safety Issues
item.data: None significant.

item.label: Average Fuel Price
item.data: Determined by power utility's prices.

item.label: Fuel Source
item.data: Corn, grains, or agricultural waste.

item.label: Vehicle Compatibility
item.data: Up to 10% mixture with regular gasoline (known as E10) can be used in today's vehicles. Higher concentrations require flex fuel vehicles.

item.label: Environmental Impacts
item.data: Vehicles running 85% ethanol/15% gasoline mixture (E85) reduce global warming gases and nitrogen oxide, but have increased emissions of formaldehyde and acetaldehyde.

item.label: Safety Issues
item.data: Less toxic than gasoline; vapors disperse more quickly than gasoline.

item.label: Fuel Source
item.data: Natural gas, methanol, or electrolysis of water.

item.label: Percent of Gasoline's Energy (per gallon)
item.data: 44.4% for 1lb of H2

item.label: Vehicle Compatibility
item.data: Currently there are no commercially available hydrogen vehicles/

item.label: Environmental Impacts
item.data: Zero tailpipe emissions for fuel cells. Pollutants are emitted from hydrogen production.

item.label: Safety Issues
item.data: Standards have been set for fuel cell vehicles, but with vehicles, there is not data. Safety record in industrial use is excellent.

item.label: Average Fuel Price
item.data: Not available.
